text: I had problems in my project

text: <@U01AYQ4HQHF> What are you actually trying to do?

elements.text: What are you actually trying to do?

text:
I have a parameterdict like this (in Finnish, I know) to store multiple types of parameters. Sometimes my program understands types but sometimes not..
```Hakemisto = Dict("Nimi" => "Kokeilu", "Yla_arvo" => "Yla_arvo", "Ala_arvo" => "Ala_arvo", "Aloituspinnankorkeus" => 2.5, "Aloitusvirtaama" => 0,
"Laskentapisteet" => 100, "Pituus" => 3700, "Pohja_alkukorko" => 0.3, "Pohja_loppukorko" => 0, "k" => 1, "Bo" => 2.5, "n" => 0.04)```

text: sounds like a problem with your dictionary construction. A struct won't help, you will just be getting error at a different step

elements.text: sounds like a problem with your dictionary construction. A struct won't help, you will just be getting error at a different step
Ok

text: Interesting.. Only way is to keep strings, ints and floats in separate places?

elements.text: Interesting.. Only way is to keep strings, ints and floats in separate places?

text:
no, you can definitely store them in the same dictionary (it becomes e.g. `Dict{String,Any}`, so the values can be of any concrete type). E.g.:

```julia> d = Dict("x" => 1, "y" => "2")
Dict{String,Any} with 2 entries:
  "x" => 1
  "y" => "2"

julia> typeof(d["x"]), typeof(d["y"])
(Int64, String)```
What I think happened is that what you thought was stored as an `Int` was actually a float or a string... you'd have to explicitly convert it to an integer to enforce that, if that's what you need

elements.text: no, you can definitely store them in the same dictionary (it becomes e.g.
Dict{String,Any}

julia> d = Dict("x" => 1, "y" => "2")
Dict{String,Any} with 2 entries:
  "x" => 1
  "y" => "2"

julia> typeof(d["x"]), typeof(d["y"])
(Int64, String)
What I think happened is that what you thought was stored as an
Int
was actually a float or a string... you'd have to explicitly convert it to an integer to enforce that, if that's what you need
Ok, thank you very much!
